A math student is given the following problem to solve related to knot theory and geometric topology:

Consider a closed, orientable 3-dimensional manifold M that is the boundary of the union of two open sets, A and B. Suppose that A is homeomorphic to the solid torus (the product of a disk with a circle), B is homeomorphic to a 3-ball, and A and B intersect in exactly one torus knot. Calculate the self-linking number of the torus knot.
message_2:
The self-linking number of a knot is an invariant that measures the linking of a knot with a push-off of itself. For a torus knot, the self-linking number can be computed using the formula:

Self-linking number = p * q - gcd(p, q)

where p and q are the parameters of the torus knot, and gcd(p, q) is the greatest common divisor of p and q.

In this problem, we are given a closed, orientable 3-dimensional manifold M that is the boundary of the union of two open sets, A and B. A is homeomorphic to the solid torus, and B is homeomorphic to a 3-ball. A and B intersect in exactly one torus knot.

Since A is homeomorphic to the solid torus, it can be parameterized by (p, q), where p and q are coprime integers (i.e., gcd(p, q) = 1). The torus knot is then a (p, q)-torus knot.

Using the formula for the self-linking number, we have:

Self-linking number = p * q - gcd(p, q)

Since p and q are coprime, gcd(p, q) = 1. Therefore, the self-linking number of the torus knot is:

Self-linking number = p * q - 1
